SENT.plain: The leaves of the Cashew plant (Anacardium occidentale L.) are used by the folk medicine in South America and West Africa
This plant is rich in flavonoids, which are polyphenolic compounds widespread in plants, and that have diverse physiological effects
In a sub-acute toxicity assay it was found that an ethanolic extract of Cashew leaves elicited lymphopenia in rats
The extract was also found to be cytotoxic and to induce apoptosis in Jurkat (acute lymphoblastic leukemia) cells
The crude ethanolic extract was fractionated and resolved by HPLC
One of the four fractions obtained led to the isolation of the biflavonoid agasthisflavone
[(3)H]-thymidine incorporation assays and flow cytometry analysis showed that the isolated compound displayed a high anti-proliferative effect in Jurkat cells with an IC(50) of 2.4 μg/ml (4.45 μM)
The effect of agathisflavone on the acute promyelocytic leukemia cell line HL60, Burkitt lymphoma Raji cells and Hep-2 laryngeal carcinoma cells was also tested
The two latter ones were only mildly affected by agathisflavone
It is also shown that agathisflavone induces apoptosis in Jurkat cells and it this proposed that this is the likely mechanism of agathisflavone specific cytotoxicity
